ACCIDENTAL RELEASE AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

It is the policy of AES Ironwood, LLC to conduct activities in such a way as to take foremost account of the health and safety of ourselves and of other persons.

We will adhere to the highest standards for the safe operation of the plant, the protection of the environment, ourselves, customers and the people in the community where we do business.

The objective of this policy is to promote good health and a high level of safety.  We believe that excellence in the management of health and safety is an essential element within our overall business plan. The identification, assessment and control of health and safety and other risks are of equal importance to production and quality.  These aims will be achieved by allocating sufficient resources to provide and maintain conditions and places of work that are, so far as reasonably practicable, safe and healthy.  Effective control of health and safety is achieved through co-operative effort at all levels in our organization.

Our policy is to provide and maintain safe and healthy working conditions, equipment and systems of work for all of us, and to provide such information, training and supervision as we need for this purpose. We also accept our responsibility for the health and safety of other people who may be working at the plant under our safety system.

The allocation of duties for safety matters and the particular arrangements that we will make to implement the policy are the overall responsibility of the Plant Manager.  The Health & Safety Coordinator will be responsible during the Plant Manager's absence. 

The Health & Safety Coordinator is responsible for:

- Safety training;

- Carrying out safety inspections;

- Investigating accidents and where necessary reporting on accidents and dangerous occurrences which may occur;

- Implementing and monitoring safe systems of work and auditing procedures; and

- Organizing the plant safety committee.

Each AES perso

n is responsible for health and safety in an area of the Plant, which is designated by his or her Leader.  Furthermore, each AES person has the responsibility to cooperate and communicate with their Team Leaders and the Plant Manager to achieve a healthy and safe workplace and to take reasonable care of themselves and others.

Whenever one of us notices a health and safety problem, which we are not immediately able to correct, we will tell the appropriate person directly.  The appropriate person may either be the Plant Leader in charge of the area in question or the Health & Safety Coordinator.

Consultation on safety issues between AES people is provided by means of the safety committee, which meets monthly, and plant communications meetings. 

This policy will be kept up to date, particularly as the business changes in nature and size.  To ensure that this takes place, the policy and the way in which it has operated will be reviewed continually.

DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The AES Ironwood Power Plant is situated within the Township of South Lebanon, in Lebanon County, Pennsylvania.  The facility is secured by a chain-link fence with controlled entry security and 24-hour manning.

The power plant is a gas-fired combustion turbine generation facility that produces electricity.  As a means of reducing nitrogen oxide emissions from the turbine combustion process, aqueous ammonia (nominally 29.4 percent ammonia by weight) is vaporized and injected into the turbine exhaust.  The ammonia acts as a reagent in the selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of nitrogen oxides across a solid catalyst bed.

The aqueous ammonia is stored on site within two side-by-side aboveground storage tanks of equal size.  The total capacity of the ammonia storage and feed system exceeds the threshold quantity for applicability to 40 CFR Part 68, the Risk Management Program (RMP) regulation.  There are no other toxic or flammable materials on site that exceed

the continual functionality of equipment and safety support systems;

- The facility conducts regular safety inspections and self-reviews of compliance with various regulations and standards; and

- In the unlikely event of their occurrence, all incidents, unsafe conditions, or other near-misses are promptly and thoroughly investigated by a qualified team to determine their cause and to implement corrective actions to ensure that the condition will not reoccur.

CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The ammonia system is designed to meet or exceed current design standards for aqueous ammonia storage and handling systems.  A detailed Hazard Review was conducted to verify design and operational safety, and to identify the potential for safety enhancements.  The analysis included the delivery and unloading of ammonia to the storage tank, as well as ammonia storage, pumping, vaporization, and injection.  As a result of the review, the facility has implemented additional measures to ensure continual operability of ammonia safety systems.

The ammonia system is subjected to preventive maintenance inspections and testing to ensure its ongoing integrity.  As part of regular duties of the operations staff, the ammonia vessels, piping, and injection system are visually inspected daily to ensure that no undue hazards are present.  The ammonia vessels are periodically subjected to precise wall thickness tests to verify their integrity.

Protection of the ammonia storage system includes a complete containment system provided around the side-by-side tanks.  In the unlikely event of an ammonia release from the tanks or their appurtenances, ammonia would be immediately contained so as to minimize potential vapor release impacts.  Provisions are in place to promptly respond to and remove any chemical that is spilled on site.

Ammonia leak detection is provided for ammonia delivery piping, which provides an immediate leak notification within the constantly-manned control room.  Plant

control systems are in place to automatically shut down the transfer of ammonia from the tanks to the process injection point in the event of a leak.

The delivery and unloading of ammonia into the tanks is strictly managed and controlled.  Tank vehicles and delivery connections are secured, tank levels are verified, and protective equipment is stationed prior to starting unloading operations.  The unloading operation is constantly manned by a trained individual who can immediately shut down ammonia transfer under abnormal conditions.  The ammonia vessels are each provided with high level alarms to minimize the potential for overfilling.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The AES Ironwood Power Plant has not experienced an accidental release of ammonia.  Therefore, no accidents have resulted in either on site or off site effects as defined in 40 CFR Part 68 for five-year accident history reporting.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The facility maintains a written emergency response program which is in place to protect worker health and public safety.  The program is coordinated with the community response plan maintained by the Lebanon County LEPC.  

Plant personnel are trained and equipped to respond to releases of ammonia.  The facility Spill Response and Emergency Action Plan includes chemical-specific procedures for responding to a release of any chemical on site, including ammonia.  The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures; evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation; and notification of local emergency response agencies if a release occurs.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The aqueous ammonia system design exceeds the latest in design standards.  The detailed Hazard Review conducted on the ammonia system identified several opportunities to increase the frequency and scope of functionality testing of several safety-critical components.  These enhancements will be inc
orporated as a permanent feature of the overall plant maintenance management system.
